thread.title: Here are the finals from the NFL:
thread.title_full: Here are the finals from the NFL:

author: wtopstaff
title: Here are the finals from the NFL:
text:
Home » News » Sports » NFL » Here are the finals… Here are the finals from the NFL: By The Associated Press October 18, 2015 8:07 pm 
SEATTLE (AP) — The Carolina Panthers have maintained their perfect record by rallying in Seattle. 
Cam Newton threw a 26-yard touchdown pass to Greg Olsen with 32 seconds left to give the 5-0 Panthers a 27-23 win over the Seahawks. Newton engineered touchdown drives on the Panthers’ last two possessions after the Seahawks grabbed a 23-14 lead. The Carolina quarterback was 12 of 15 for 169 yards in the fourth quarter to finish with 269 yards overall. 
Jonathan Stewart also sparked the rally with his second one-yard TD run of the afternoon. Stewart had 78 yards on 20 carries. 
Seahawks QB Russell Wilson threw for 239 yards and ran for another 53, but the defending NFC champs are 2-4 following their second straight fourth-quarter meltdown. Marshawn Lynch finished with 54 yards and a touchdown on 17 carries in his return to the Seattle lineup. 
SAN DIEGO (AP) — The Green Bay Packers are 6-0 after Aaron Rodgers passed for two touchdowns and James Starks had a 65-yard TD run in a 27-20 triumph at San Diego. The Packers blew a 17-3 lead before Rodgers hit James Jones for a tiebreaking, eight-yard scoring strike with 46 seconds left in the third quarter. 
Rodgers finished with 255 passing yards and Starks had another 112 on the ground to help the Packers overcome a production game by Philip Rivers. 
The outcome was in doubt until the Packers stopped San Diego on fourth-and-goal from the 3 with 15 seconds left. Rookie cornerback Damarious Randall lunged to poke away Rivers’ short pass to Danny Woodhead near the front right pylon to clinch it. 
Rivers threw for two touchdowns while setting career highs with 43 completions, 65 attempts and 503 yards. Rivers’ two scoring passes wiped out the Chargers’ 14-point deficit before they dropped to 2-4. 
ORCHARD PARK, N.Y. (AP) — Andy Dalton threw three touchdown passes to lead unbeaten Cincinnati to a 34-21 win over Buffalo. The Bengals sixth straight victory matches the team’s best start to a season. 
Dalton completed touchdown passes to Marvin Jones, Tyler Eifert and Jeremy Hill. Jones had nine receptions for 95 yards. 
Dalton finished 22 of 33 for 243 yards for Cincinnati, which was also 6-0 to start the 1975 and ’88 seasons. 
The Bengals broke the game open by scoring 17 points on their first three second-half possessions to build a 34-14 lead. 
The 3-3 Bills were undone by injuries and several penalties that allowed the Bengals to enjoy an average drive start of midfield in the first half. 
Bills backup quarterback EJ Manuel started in place of Tyrod Taylor, who was sidelined with a sprained left knee. Manuel finished 28 of 42 for 263 yards with a touchdown and interception. LeSean McCoy rushed for 90 yards on 17 carries and a touchdown for Buffalo. 
CLEVELAND (AP) — Peyton Manning shook off three interceptions and drove Denver in range for Brandon McManus’ 34-yard field goal with 4:56 left in overtime for a 26-23 win over Cleveland. 
Manning took the Broncos from their 12 to the Cleveland 16 before McManus kicked his game-winner to make Denver 6-0 for the seventh time in franchise history. 
The Broncos top-ranked defense came up big in overtime. 
After Manning’s third pick, Denver recorded two sacks to push the 2-4 Browns out of field-goal range. 
Manning completed 4 of 4 passes for 39 yards on the last drive. 
The extra period came after a frenetic fourth quarter during which Cleveland took the lead on an interception return only to have Manning take it back 14 seconds later with a 75-yard touchdown pass. 
DETROIT (AP) — Matt Prater kicked a 27-yard field goal with 2:29 left in overtime to lift Detroit over Chicago 37-34 for the Lions first victory of the season. 
Matthew Stafford heaved a 57-yard pass to Calvin Johnson to set up the kick for the 1-5 Lions. Johnson finished with six receptions for 166 yards and a score. 
Stafford threw a go-ahead, 6-yard touchdown pass to a leaping Johnson in the end zone with 21 seconds left in the fourth following consecutive penalties. 
Then Chicago’s Robbie Gould (GOHLD) kicked a 29-yard field goal as time expired in regulation. The tying score was set up on consecutive pass interference calls against the Lions Darius Slay. 
PITTSBURGH (AP) — Landry Jones threw two touchdown passes to Martavis Bryant in relief of Michael Vick, sending Pittsburgh to a 25-13 win over Arizona. 
Vick left in the third quarter with a hamstring injury and Pittsburgh’s offense took off when Jones took over. Jones hit Bryant for an 8-yard score to give the Steelers the lead. The two hooked up later for an 88-yard strike as the 4-3 Steelers won their second straight. 
Jones completed 8 of 12 passes for 168 yards and the two scores. Bryant caught six passes for 137 yards in his first action of the season. Le’Veon Bell ran for 88 yards and rookie Chris Boswell kicked three long field goals for the Steelers. 
Carson Palmer threw for 421 yards with a touchdown and two interceptions for the Cardinals who fall to 4-2. John Brown caught 10 balls for 196 yards for Arizona. 
EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. (AP) — Ryan Fitzpatrick threw two touchdown passes and ran for another score to key the New York Jets 34-20 win over Washington. 
Chris Ivory ran for 146 yards and a TD on 20 carries for the Jets, who improved to 4-1 for the first time since 2010. Brandon Marshall had seven catches for 111 yards, and Eric Decker also caught a TD. 
Washington led 13-10 at halftime thanks to points off of three turnovers, all by Bashaud Breeland. 
But New York opened the second half with 24 straight points to take control against a 2-4 Washington team without several starters, including wide receiver DeSean Jackson and cornerbacks DeAngelo Hall and Chris Culliver. 
Kirk Cousins finished with a touchdown and two interceptions for the Redskins. 
NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) — Cameron Wake got his first four sacks this season and also forced two fumbles helping Miami beat Tennessee 38-10 in Dan Campbell’s debut as interim coach. 
The 2-3 Dolphins entered the game having lost three straight, costing coach Joe Philbin his job Oct. 5. 
The Dolphins finished with six sacks and intercepted Marcus Mariota twice. The rookie quarterback needed a knee brace and was replaced by Zach Mettenberger after the 2-minute warning. 
Jarvis Landry scored Miami’s first rushing touchdown of the season and Lamar Miller ran for 113 yards and a TD. 
The 1-4 Titans lost their fourth straight. 
SANTA CLARA, Calif. (AP) — Torrey Smith and Anquan Boldin had some fun at their former team’s expense. Smith hooked up with Colin Kaepernick (KAP’-ur-nik) for a 76-yard touchdown reception in San Francisco’s 25-20 triumph against Baltimore. Boldin’s 51-yard grab set up Quinton Patton’s 21-yard TD catch that put the 49ers ahead 25-13 with 10:52 left. 
Phil Dawson kicked four field goals and the 49ers intercepted Joe Flacco twice in ending a four-game losing streak and improving to 2-4. 
Steve Smith had a 34-yard scoring grab for the 1-5 Ravens, who are off to the worst six-game start in team history. 
MINNEAPOLIS (AP) — Rookie wide receiver Stefon Diggs had 129 yards on seven catches to help overcome two Teddy Bridgewater interceptions in Minnesota’s 16-10 win over Kansas City. 
Adrian Peterson finished with 60 yards on 26 carries for the Vikings who improved to 3-2. Blair Walsh kicked four fleld goals for the Vikings. 
Bridgewater passed for 143 yards in the first quarter, but ended what had been a smooth opening drive, by throwing an interception in the end zone. 
Alex Smith threw a 42-yard touchdown pass to Albert Wilson midway in the fourth quarter for the 1-5 Chiefs but it wasn’t enough to overcome a sloppy performance. 
Running back Charcandrick West lost a fumble down the stretch and the Chiefs had eight penalties enforced for 95 yards. 
JACKSONVILLE, Fla. (AP) — Brian Hoyer threw three touchdown passes on third down to lead Houston to a 31-20 victory over Jacksonville. DeAndre Hopkins grabbed two of the scoring tosses to help the Texas improve to 2-4. 
Hoyer regained the starting job last week against Indianapolis and looked deserving of the spot. 
Andre Hal returned an interception 41 yards for a touchdown for the 2-4 Texas. It was the sixth pick-six thrown by Jacksonville quarterback Blake Bortles in 19 career starts. The 1-5 Jaguars have lost four in a row. Topics:
